subject: RE: [junit] Is there a place for private methods with TDD?
msgSnippet: ... Was the class in question designed through the application of TDD?  If so, what is C doing that is extra to what A and B need, and therefore covered by
messageBody:
>
> In a class (see below) with two public methods A & B that
> both call private method C, what's the best approach for unit
> testing it? Should test scenarios for A or B cover what may
> happen in C ? If so, is it just accepted as a code management
> overhead to ensure that C is properly tested via tests for A or B ?
>

Was the class in question designed through the application of TDD? If so,
what is C doing that is extra to what A and B need, and therefore covered by
their tests?

I hope you can forgive me the extravagance of quoting myself from last
month:

Test First means that very few of my methods are private, and I really don't
see this as a bad thing. (Most of the ones that are private are there only
because that's what Eclipses' Extract Method refactoring does).

NB: That is not the same as making private methods public for testing
purposes. That should be avoided at all costs.

Regards,
Shaun.
